Minecraft for parents: Strange creatures live in our basement: endermen, ender dragons, cave spiders, zombies, creepers and the like. And of course my boys!
Should I be worried now?
Here comes the all clear:

Interjection on my own behalf:

Dear people!
Welcome to the family blog “Muttis Nähkästchen”

For everyone who doesn’t know us yet: Chat here Birgit and Christine out of the sewing box and write about that (Survive) life with children. We strive to provide valuable content that you really help. Besides, we always come back fine things for you to raffle.

First of all: Your child is crazy about Minecraft?
Then I speak mine at this point sympathy out. And mine at the same time warmest congratulations!

congratulations?
yes, congratulations Because unlike first-person shooters, this game constructive!

Minecraft is constructive!

(Well, unless they’re listening to some Youtuber and want to play Bed Wars – but that’s another story…). in the creative mode can be built to your heart’s content. in the survival mode you also have to cope with some adversities, such as hunger (oh what!). And it’s going quite peacefully. So just to keep hungry you have to butcher a pig every now and then… or roast a chicken. (Don’t eat the latter raw – it could contain salmonella, which could poison you. And then the hunger pangs are lost very quickly.)
And my kids know: You can also install a vegan mod – so everything is easy!
The bottom line here is respect and creativity:

Mining and crafting instead of beating and shooting.

And condolences…
Because your kids will become one speak language, where you probably only understand train station. be there mob and monster spawned, biomes researched, mods tried out, skins created, diamond swords crafted and one Enderman it’s better not to look into the eyes…
huh?!?
In addition, there is a very high probability that your children will never voluntarily stop playing… Your kid is one of 100 million gamers who just can’t tear themselves away? It’s not alone: ​​as of May 2016, it’s ranked as the second highest-grossing game of all time (behind Tetris).

BUT: Minecraft help is here:
(quasi a cheat sheet for the producer faction!)

Minecraft for parents

Also for people who would not necessarily count themselves among the nerds – me, for example! – benefit from this book. Particularly nerdy sections are marked – like spicy food on a menu – and can be skipped if necessary. It helped me a lot to understand my sons’ gibberish. On top of that, in addition to facts and tips, the book also offers plenty of anti-frustration solutions. Definitely recommended reading for all concerned parents.
Here’s a little foretaste:

Essential Minecraft knowledge for parents

With the kind permission of the publisher:

What kids love about Minecraft

But first things first, what is it that makes Minecraft so irresistible for kids (and the young at heart)?

Creative, cool and easy

  • One can feel extraordinary creative actuate; comparable to Lego, but larger and programmable.
  • The environment is “cool”: It is technically modern, because you play on the PC or on the console, but retro-stylish in the minimalistic game – the contrast makes it.
  • There is few easy-to-learn rules of the game.
  • Of the retro minimalism hits not only that ZeitgeistBlocks just got it: Bricks, cement blocks, Lego bricks, Minecraft blocks – all share the same irresistible need to be piled on top of each other to build something.

I’m the boss here!

  • the First person perspective of the character helps to delve into the game world.
  • That Homely and adventurer feeling: In Minecraft you can set up a (virtual digital) headquarters in a safe place to start risky adventures in all directions from there.
  • The players have power of decision about construction and destruction without any consequences in real life.

Pleasant gaming experience

  • the feel is stimulating: It ranges from simple and effective controls to pleasantly accompanying sound effects such as the satisfying popping sound when mining materials.
  • That gameplay offers the right balance between challenge and reward, fun and creativity.
  • Creativity again: In all its facets and channels (including the online community), not only the game, but the entire Minecraft theme offers countless opportunities for expression.
  • For introverts and extroverts and the many human profiles in between: Either you play Minecraft alone or togetherwhen meeting like-minded people online. Or you can find the ideal path in between in the huge range of Minecraft activities.
  • For the younger ones: There is a lot to see. Even if the child is too young for all aspects of play, the basic learning process – watch and imitate – is triggered as the child sits next to the older brother or sister or watches the YouTube heroes.
  • Teamwork: Experimenting together and achieving something – this develops skills in thinking, mathematics, geometry, spatial thinking and even teaches a touch of geology. The immediate application of what has been learned creates a feeling of reward including the appropriate hormones.
  • Big projects require intensive planning, sub-goals and more detailed team organization, almost like a real job. The fun of this satisfying “work” and the feeling of reward from the result are in turn appealing.
    © Rheinwerk Verlag, Bonn 2018

Minecraft for Parents: What Mom Learned

And now I’ll tell you a little about what I’ve learned there:

  • Good to know:

    Monsters cannot see through glass – very convenient. Also, they don’t spawn near torches – so always light things up nicely!
    For a trip to the Nether always enough quarry stone carry! Helps against the fireballs of the nether ghasts.
    Mobs and monsters do not spawn on clear blocks.
    Obsidian is the second hardest material in Minecraft and can also withstand creepers and TNT.
    An Enderman should never look in the eye. Because then he gets red eyes and attacks! (Remedy: Put on the pumpkin.)
    Complex machines can be crafted with Redstone as an energy source.

  • Minecraft is extensible:

    Various extensions are available for download on the Internet: skins, resource packs, maps, mods (modifications – such as JurassiCraft with dinosaurs). Such extensions are often recommended in relevant YouTube videos – and then of course the child must have something like that. Well, a double-edged sword … By the way: The maps have ready-made Hogwarts landscapes/buildings for Harry Potter fans or Westeros for Game of Thrones fans. The book mentioned above explains how to install something like this.

  • Online multiplayer is more fun…

    But it is also more challenging for parents. Because: Not every multi-player server offers harmless content and, as is well known, there are idiots everywhere. A multiplayer game or your own Minecraft server in the home network may be a viable alternative. But then it gets really nerdy – even if the book accompanies you well.

  • Safe on the Internet:

    The book not only reveals knowledge for Minecraft itself, but also how parents can create a – reasonably – safe environment so that their children do not end up on dubious portals and content on the Internet or accidentally download malware. Thumbs up! Even my “house nerd” got some ideas from there… And I always thought it couldn’t get any more nerdy…

  • Last but not least: cats help against creepers.

    But you have to tame this cat first: hold out the raw fish, don’t wave it around or jump around, then the cat will come – maybe.
